content:
Cakewalk是一家位于马萨诸塞州波士顿的前音乐制作软件公司，目前是新加坡音乐公司BandLab Technologies的旗下品牌。该公司最著名的产品是他们的专业级数字音频工作站(DAW) 软件SONAR。SONAR 集成了数字音频和MIDI的多轨录音和编辑。该公司还提供全系列的音乐软件产品，包括 Pyro Audio Creator（一种数字音乐管理程序）和 Dimension Pro（一种虚拟乐器）。

 

该品牌于 2013 年被Gibson收购，2017 年 Gibson 宣布停止 Cakewalk 的开发。2018 年，总部位于新加坡的 BandLab Technologies 购买了 Cakewalk部分资产，并继续进行 SONAR 开发，作为其免费软件数字音频工作站软件组合的一部分。

 

历史

Greg Hendershott 于 1987 年创立了该公司，当时名为Twelve Tone Systems，并在 2012 年 7 月 1 日之前一直担任该公司的首席执行官。该公司很快发现，大多数客户都以其初始产品的名称来称呼它，Hendershott 拥有的MIDI 音乐音序器名为Cakewalk。为避免混淆，该公司多年来一直以“十二音系统公司DBA Cakewalk”的名义运营。

 

该公司于 1987 年发布了适用于MS-DOS的原始 MIDI 音乐音序器产品Cakewalk。1991年，他们发布了适用于Windows 3.0的版本。

 

DOS 版本（最高 3.0）的早期Cakewalk需要MPU-401的智能模式，因此不能与 MPU-401 的产品克隆一起使用，而后来的 Cakewalk 版本（自 4.0 起）依赖于“哑巴” UART仅模式。随着更新了更多功能，该公司将音序器更名为Cakewalk Pro，然后在获得对数字化音频的支持后更名为Cakewalk Pro Audio。

 

在SONAR 的数字音频工作站允许用户创建可以自行编辑的数字音轨、MIDI音轨和喜欢的歌词和乐谱相关的信息项目。SONAR 的视觉显示包括音频波形、乐谱、编辑控制台和事件列表。用户可以将 MIDI 输出和音轨混合成立体声 .WAV 文件并将其刻录到CD或以其他媒体格式发布。

 

2008 年 1 月，公司产品上的标识更改为“Cakewalk by Roland”，以反映Roland Corporation购买了该公司的多数股权。

 

2008 年 9 月，公司正式更名为“Cakewalk, Inc.”。

 

自 2012 年 7 月 1 日起，Greg Hendershott 在公司任职 25 年后辞去首席执行官一职。前产品执行副总裁 Michael Hoover 成为 Cakewalk的总裁。2013 年 12 月 6 日，Roland 将其在 Cakewalk 的所有股份出售给Gibson Brands。在接下来的 5 年中，Cakewalk 继续在波士顿开展业务，为 Cakewalk 品牌开发产品，以及与TASCAM 的联合产品。

 

2017 年 11 月 17 日，Gibson 宣布将停止后续开发和生产 Cakewalk 品牌产品。30 年后，Cakewalk停止运营，只有该公司的网络论坛和许可授权服务器仍在运行。

 

2018 年 2 月 23 日，总部位于新加坡的 BandLab Technologies 宣布购买 Cakewalk的部分资产及其所有知识产权。BandLab 的既定目标是继续开发前公司的旗舰产品 SONAR（现在 BandLab 更名为 Cakewalk），作为其免费软件数字音频工作站软件组合的一部分。

 

产品

公司产品包括音序器；数字音频工作站，包括 Bandlab 当前的 Cakewalk，以及以前的产品 Dimension Pro 和 Rapture Pro（多采样合成器）；以及用于创作音乐的乐器、效果工具和其他付费产品。
contentEn:
Cakewalk, Inc. is a former music production software company based in Boston, Massachusetts and currently a brand of Singaporean music company BandLab Technologies. The company's best known product was their professional-level digital audio workstation (DAW) software, SONAR. SONAR integrated multi-track recording and editing of digital audio and MIDI. The company also offered a full range of music software products, including Pyro Audio Creator—a digital music management program, and Dimension Pro—a virtual instrument.

 

The brand was acquired in 2013 by Gibson, and in 2017 Gibson announced it was ceasing Cakewalk development. In 2018, Singapore-based BandLab Technologies purchased some of Cakewalk, Inc.'s assets, and continued SONAR development as part of its portfolio of freeware digital audio workstation software.

 

History

Greg Hendershott founded the company in 1987 as Twelve Tone Systems, Inc., and was its CEO until July 1, 2012. The firm soon found that most customers referred to it by the name of its initial product, a MIDI music sequencer that Hendershott had named Cakewalk. To avoid confusion, the company operated for many years as "Twelve Tone Systems, Inc. DBA Cakewalk".

 

The company released the original MIDI music sequencer product, Cakewalk, for MS-DOS in 1987. In 1991, they released a version for Windows 3.0.

 

Early Cakewalk for DOS versions (up to 3.0) required the intelligent mode of the MPU-401, and so could not be used with product clones of the MPU-401, while later Cakewalk versions (since 4.0) relied on the "dumb" UART mode only. With the addition of more features, the company renamed the sequencer Cakewalk Pro, and then Cakewalk Pro Audio when it gained support for digitized audio.

 

The SONAR digital audio workstation provided users the ability to create projects in which they could edit digital audio tracks, MIDI tracks, and associated information like lyrics and music notation. SONAR's visual displays included audio waveforms, musical scores, editing consoles, and event lists. The user could mix MIDI output and audio tracks down to a stereo .WAV file and burn it to a CD or publish it in other media formats.

 

In January 2008, the logo on the company's products changed to "Cakewalk by Roland" to reflect Roland Corporation's purchase of a majority interest in the company.[1]

 

In September 2008, the company officially changed its corporate name to 'Cakewalk, Inc.'[2]

 

Effective July 1, 2012, Greg Hendershott resigned as CEO, after 25 years with the company. Michael Hoover, previously Executive Vice President of Products, became President of Cakewalk, Inc.[3] On December 6, 2013, Roland sold all of its shares of Cakewalk to Gibson Brands. For the next 5 years, Cakewalk continued to operate in Boston, developing products for the Cakewalk brand, along with joint products with TASCAM.[citation needed]

 

On November 17, 2017, Gibson announced[4] that it was ceasing active development and production of Cakewalk branded products. After 30 years, Cakewalk, Inc. ceased operation, with only the company's web forum and license authorization servers still being kept functional.

 

On February 23, 2018, Singapore-based BandLab Technologies announced its purchase of some of Cakewalk, Inc.’s assets and all of its intellectual property.[5] BandLab's stated goal was continued development of the former company's flagship product, SONAR (now renamed Cakewalk by BandLab) as part of its portfolio of freeware digital audio workstation software.

 

Products

The company's products included sequencers; digital audio workstations, including the current Cakewalk by Bandlab, and former products Dimension Pro and Rapture Pro (Multisample synth);[6][7] and instruments, effects tools and miscellaneous consumer products for creating music.

 

References

  1. ^ Roland acquires majority of Cakewalk, by Peter Kirn. Published 18 August 2008 by the Create Digital Music blog. Despite the impression given in this report's opening sentence, only the product logo, not the company name, changed to Cakewalk by Roland.
  2. ^ Cakewalk Announces Corporate Name Change, official press release, 2 September 2008.
  3. ^ Michael Hoover named new President of Cakewalk, The Cakewalk Blog, 25 June 2012.
  4. ^ http://www.cakewalk.com/Gibson-Announcement
  5. ^ https://blog.bandlab.com/cakewalk-press-release/ BandLab Technologies Announces Acquisition of Cakewalk Inc. Assets retrieved 23 February 2018
  6. ^ "Cakewalk Dimension Pro". Sound On Sound. May 2006. Archived from the original on 3 March 2016.
  7. ^ "Cakewalk Rapture". Sound On Sound. August 2006. Archived from the original on 19 September 2015.
remarks:
